title: How to Take a Pattern by Rubbing

steps.headline: Choose a suitable piece of paper for transferring the pattern to.
steps.description: The paper should be of a good medium thickness. If it is too thick, it will not take a clear impression of the pattern, and if it is very thin, it is apt to tear. Paper used for letter writing or printing is often a suitable choice.

steps.headline: Prepare the embroidery.
steps.description: Lay the embroidery piece, the right side up, flat upon a board or table and cover it with the paper.

steps.headline: Fasten the paper down upon the embroidery with drawing pins.
Rub off the pattern with a crayon.
steps.description: Powdered graphite or charcoal will also work. You could even rub over the embroidery using a large coin - the outlines will not, of course, be very clearly defined upon the paper and will have to be gone over and carefully supplemented afterwards with a pencil.

steps.headline: Use the pattern as required.
steps.description: As soon as you have fixed the lines of the pattern by drawing them over with ink, it is ready for use.

Prepare the embroidery. Lay the embroidery piece, the right side up, flat upon a board or table and cover it with the paper. Fasten the paper down upon the embroidery with drawing pins.  Rub off the pattern with a crayon. Powdered graphite or charcoal will also work.
